content:
Posted: July 3, 2015
												This is a game. About pirate ships. That fly. And have large missile launchers, flamethrowers and a large assortment of other weapons. And you can shoot those. At other flying pirate ships. If that doesn't sound good to you, you clearly had no childhood.The idea of this game is to use your ariship to shoot down other airships. The core concept is very simple, and doesn't require Counter-Strike levels of aiming skill. However, don't let that fool you into thinking this game requires no skill. You still need to coordinate and compensate for movement on guns. The guns aren't hitscan like CS, which means you must compensate for projectile movement and lead your targets.There are 3 different roles:Pilot: Pilots the ship. Duh. Has several abilities to change ship functions, such as adding speed. Most of these damage some ship component.Engineer: Fixes anything that breaks/explodes. Can use fire extinguishers, and wield more than one repair tool. You can have 3 at one time, allowing you to adapt your fixing method depending on how many parts have exploded/lit on fire.Gunner: Holds different types of ammo that allows him to adapt to different situations. Need more fire? Got it. Need faster bullets? Sure!Each of these roles must work together in a crew of four to destroy enemy ships. The built in voice chat is excellent, providing you a great way to work together with teammates. If you don't have a mic, don't play this game. You won't enjoy it. The teamwork itself is quite satisfying(10 DEGREES TO PORT, CAPN! GET THAT HULL BACK UP, ENGIE!), and this is the part of the game that I enjoy the most. The multiplayer has a commendation system built in, as well as a report system. Most of the community is very friendly, and the salty ones get weeded out quickly.As for the variety, everything is unlocked from the start, meaning you can use every ship in the game(provided you're willing to get wrecked your first few games with large ships). Every gun on these ships is replaceable, allowing you to create your own loadouts suited for every situation. Sniper? Sure. Close range bruiser? You got it. Each crew member has a custom loadout that can be edited from the start as well.New to the game? Don't worry, there's a specific section of muiltiplayer dedicated to level 10 or below players. This limits the ships you can use to some simpler ones to get you used to the game. If you like, you can skip right into regular matchmaking.I highly recommend this game. The devs are great and still provide quality updates. I have no clue why people say this game is dead, there are 3K plus players online at any time. Filling lobbies is easy, getting everyone to ready up is the hard part. :P

Product received for free
												Do you like working in a team? Do you like chaotic situations? Do you like shooting down airships? If you answered yes to any of these questions, you'll probably like Guns of Icarus Online. Piloting a ship requires close coordination between the pilot, engineers, and gunners to make sure you can down other ships without being destroyed yourselves. Communication with other ships on your team is vital. Matches usually go one of two ways: someone isn't listening and it all falls apart, or everyone works together and beautiful things happen. Winning in Guns of Icarus requires both skill and teamwork—and that's why I love it.(Note: I recieved this game as a gift from a friend, so I checked the "recieved this for free" box. I have had no direct contact with the developers, and this review is my opinion alone.)(P.S. If this review motivated you to purchase Guns of Icarus (or you just want a code to enter), use my referral code nPv5xw so we can both get some gifts ingame! Just click the Community button in the top left, then click Review and Recruit in the bottom right. You only have 30 days to enter a code from account creation, so make sure you enter someone's code.)

Posted: January 27, 2015
												*I am redoing this review because there have been a lot of updates recently and some of my opinions have changed as I have played more of this game.*Guns of Icarus Online throws you onto the deck of an airship with either three friends, three players you've never met, or three AI (which are really well done in this game, I'd rather have one on my ship than a new-ish player). You will have chosen one of three unique classes, each with a very specific role on the ship. Because this game is about ship-to-ship combat rather than characters fighting, you have no health bar, no weapons, and you cannot leave your ship. Your job is to be one of the four players or AI that function as a ship, and your ship is the equivalent of your character in a match of, say, Team Fortress 2.The ships in Guns of Icarus Online are all unique, and are comparable to a class-based game like TF2. They range in difficuly from the easy to learn, hard to master Pyramidion and Goldfish to the unwieldy but deadly Spire, Squid, and Mobula. Advanced captains and crews with often only choose one of two or three ships before a match, since each ship is like a small FPS level with the guns, helm, hull, balloon, and engines in different places for each, and these crews will want to know their ship inside and out. It is very important to choose a ship that everyone on your crew feels comfortable with, and if not, choose a beginner level ship (not to say that beginner ships are any worse than the advanced ones, this game is fairly well balanced).With all this talk about crews and captains, maybe you're wondering how the lobby system works? Well, I'm sorry to say that joining a match can sometimes be a pain, especially with such a small playerbase and a rather bad auto-match-finding button. You used to be able to just scroll through the servers and choose a game, which was much easier and faster (not to mention you could see how many people were in it and what gamemode it was before joining). Once you are in a lobby, things can take a while because it is essentially the "briefing room" for each team and crew. Once a gamemode (TDM, KOTH, or a KOTH variant called "Crazy King") and a map (Since the game is using an older version of Unity and the graphics are nothing special, many of the maps feel the same), your team (2 ships, 3 ships, or 4 ships) will begin to sort out which crew is piloting which ship, if they want more than one of the same ship, loadouts, etc. Captains can edit the ship and loadout for their crew, and even change the name (I've seen everything from "Basilisk" to "Spirit of [insert name from anime]" to "YO MAMMA" to "i dont know wha im doing"). Captains can also change the paint job on their ships and change the guns. Guns are found in two sizes: light and heavy. Each ship has light hardpoints where you can only mount light guns and sometimes heavy hardpoints where you can only mount heavy guns.Classes work similarly, with the only difference between them being their loadouts. Loadouts in this game are items or tools. Each class can equip 5 items, 3 items their class uses and 1 that each other class uses. For example, the Engineer class can equip 3 engi items used to repair or buff parts of the ship, 1 gunner item which is a special type of ammo used to change the attributes of a gun, and 1 pilot item which can be used to move faster in a certain way, slow the ship down, or deploy a smokescreen among other tricks.The soundtrack to this game is great, as is the steampunk art style. The maps are creatively designed with giant buildings, shipwrecks, and mountains sometimes making mazes that are difficult to navigate. Dust clouds are a constant problem for any ship, as the more nasty ones will eat away at you engines, guns, balloon, and hull. However, clouds can be used to your advantage as they hide your ship and make it very hard to spot.The community for this game is one of the best, despite being very small. There are many community created cosmetic items added through the Steam Workshop that have made their way into the in-game store, which only sells cosmetics for players and ships (No P2W here!).The last thing I'll talk about is the upcoming Co-Op and Adventure Mode gamemodes. Co-Op will give you a chance to fight against waves of AI planes and small airships while keeping your ship alive. This leads up to Adventure Mode, which is the planned MMO world based on factions, trading, piracy, and lore. It has been delayed multiple times, so it probably won't be out anytime soon.My final thoughts:This game is great for anyone that enjoys games that require teamwork and a healthy dose of competition. It's also a must-buy for fans of anything steampunk. It has mediocre graphics and optimization, sometimes aggravating waiting times, but the gameplay makes it all worth it.I'd put it at a 9/10If you read this far, I'm genuinely amazed :P

												How do you know a PvP game is good? You have fun losing. I have never had a bad time playing this game. It can be intense. The strategy is remarkably deep. Best team PvP game since Quake Wars.And important stuff about actual gameplay aside, it's pretty too. The whole steampunk Zeppelin fighting thing is absurd but it's just far enough out to let you gloss over things like how hull-armor is a machine you repair but not so far out that if feels silly or arbitrary like if it was some kind of magic spell you were maintaining.I cannot more strongly reccomend playing.

Posted: December 9, 2013
												I've never seen a game like this - and I'm saying that in the best way possible. It's basically a cooperative steampunk dirigible deathmatch - you can play as:Engineer - fixing the ship's systems and ensuring the ship won't fall apart,Gunner - gunning down enemies' ships to ensure your team has the upper hand and a winning chance, or the Pilot, whose strategic vision and skillful flight insures that the Gunner has a target to be shooting at and the Engineer to have enough time to repair everything.Immensely fun steampunk strategy/shooter/teamwork builder.And the best part is that the developers are in the global chat almost always and are these veeery cool fellas with great vision - they're currently working on an ADVENTURE MODE - AN OPEN WORLD of steampunk exploration, collaboration and general awesomeness.I would totally recommend this game to everyone who loves steampunk, wants to break the ordinary and NEEDS a breath of fresh, awesome air.

Posted: January 8, 2016
												Guns of Icarus Online is a steampunk/dieselpunk, multiplayer, first-person shooter that focuses on airship combat. Each airship is controlled by up to four players, with each member of the crew taking a specific role. Players can choose three different classes: gunner, engineer or pilot, which will allow them access to different kinds of tools. The captain of each ship chooses which weapons to use in his/her ship. There are also several ships available:    Galleon: the Galleon is by far the biggest and more resilient ship. It is, however, the slowest. It focuses on high firepower and tank capabilities.    Squid: the Squid is the fastest ship in the game which allows its commander to outmaneuver enemy ships. It is also one of the weakest.    Goldfish: the Goldfish has a main gun on its prow, and two secondary guns on the port and starboard sides. It relies on its moderate speed and high maneuverability.    Junker: the Junker has 5 small weapon mountings. It also has high maneuverability, but a slow speed.    Pyramidion: the Pyramidion has two guns on the top deck and two on the low deck. With very high damage output, but slow turning speed, this ship is very versatile.    Spire: the Spire has a very high turning speed, but a very low linear speed. It is a high dps ship with very low hull armor.    Mobula: the Mobula has 5 weapons on the front and none on the sides or the back. It has great vertical movement, but is hard to repair in the heat of the battle.On December 23, 2011, Muse Games launched a Kickstarter project to raise $10,000 to partially fund the development of Guns of Icarus Online, and the company subsequently received $35,237 at the close of the bidding on 21 February 2012.

Posted: December 9, 2015
												Guns of Icarus is good! (for a more in depth review see below)Guns of Icarus is a game heavily focused on teamwork. If you are not a team player, this game is not for you. However if you are looking for a great team orientated game with lots of features (including three similar yet somewhat different classes, ship and character customization, detailed maps and more) then this game is definitely for you!The graphics, although not the best, are still fairly good and the art style is something I haven't seen done right in a while. The gameplay itself is amazing, with a crew consisting of a pilot and three other players which can be either engineers or gunners. The objective of the game is to destroy your opponents ships whilst keeping yours in the air (good luck in doing that if you have a pilot who drives like a toddler behind a toy wheel). This simple objective makes for some amazing moments where sometimes you find yourself ganging up on some of your closest friends (you may find yourself screaming at them because they failed to fix the balloon in time or steer away from the big pointy rock...).Overall I believe that Guns of Icarus is a great game with massive potential. The only downside is the lack of interest in the game nowadays. Sometimes you find that it's really difficult to find an open game in your region which can obviously be a negative since this game is strictly an online multiplayer only game.I rate 8/10 for Guns of Icarus

Posted: September 3, 2015
												Definitely one of the most enjoyable coop games I had the chance to play (provided you find the right people, that is, but that is an issue all games have).+Purely experience and skill-based game, with no reliance on level or exclusive equipment to defeat opponents+Various playstyle possibilities depending on your airship type, its loadout and your equipment.+With all the games dependant on quick reflexes and APM more than anything else, a game basing your proficiency on tactical and strategic approach is definitely a blow of fresh air in the teamwork-oriented PvP games.+Aesthetically pleasing+Steampunk *_* (dieselpunk, whatevs, you get the "drill" :P)+Heavily teamwork reliant, at the same time clearly set goals and easy approach make it easier for people to actually work TOGETHER in a teamwork-oriented game for a change.+Challenging, and always leaving a room for improvement in your ship destroying efficiency.+One of the best gaming communities out there :*-(Applies to open games only, doesn't really affect premade teams)Either takes a long time to start a match OR you start a match fast with people not knowing the plan behind your ship and its choice of layout.-Some achievements are RIDICULOUSLY hard to do (sorry, completionists :<)

Posted: February 8, 2016
												Some of you will probably be on the fence about buying this game; well, if one strager's opinion is enough to push you to the right choice, then take mine. This game of high caliber, if you enjoy team-based conflict with a complex network of support, and its graphics are quite nice. There are many maps to play on, and even a practice map for people looking to organize themselves or test their flying prowess. If you didn't figure out already, Guns of Icarus is about teams of 2-4 airships with crews of 4 fighting to the death in midair. The game is set in a steampunk-like world, and the three classes, engineer, gunner and pilot must work together, along with other tam ships to destroy the other team and keep their ship alive. So if that's your thing, this is the game for you. Unless you don't have friends. This game is way more fun with friends in a skype call. Good Graphics- +2Steampunk- +1Hard to play without friends- -26-directional movement- +2Multiple customizable airships- +1Hours of fun- +1Fun to play with friends- +38/10 Play all the time. But not without friends.

Posted: February 14, 2016
												Guns of Icarus is probably one of the most rewarding team-based games I have ever played, but it is not without its flaws.The good:+All 3 classes are distinct and you need a healthy mix in order to play well.+Both the ships and guns all play rather differently, but mastering them all feels great.+The maps have a nice variety to them and feature both cover, sandstorms and open ground.+All in-game items for sale are purely cosmetic and you can even unlock some as you play.+Almost every victory feels rewarding as it requires a lot from the entire team.The bad:-The soundtrack is rather limited, although judging from the dev updates that might change soon.-Communication is key, so if you or your team members don't have a mic and refuse to talk - you'll lose.-The game is currently multiplayer only, so wait times can be rather long before finding a match.Bottom Line:Guns of Icarus is an absolutely fantastic niche title that mixes steampunk, co-op ship management and even arena combat to make for a great experience. However, I would recommend picking up the 4-pack so you have friends to play with as going in completely alone can lead to a poor experience.

Posted: January 13, 2013
												Guns of icarus is a team based game where in you fly a zeppelin with your crew consisting of four people with three roles to choose from, Pilot, Engineer, and Gunner. Choose your ship, your guns, your equipment and duke it out in 2v2 team death matches.This game is extremly original with the exception of one other game similiar to it. It focuses very hard on competitive team play and has a slightly high learning curve.The only downfall this game really has is that you can buy cosmetic items in a real currency cash shop to deck out your player in cool clothes, even though they are strictly cosmetic and no effect on gameplay whatsoever they are slightly on the expensive side and the fact you have to pay for the game and you still see a microtransaction shop leaves a sour taste in the mouth.But overall guns of icarus is a fantastic game especially if you and your friends are looking for a great team based game to play with each other. Solid 8/10

Posted: June 22, 2015
												This game is a hidden gem. If you have friends to play with (preferrably in a LAN setting) then you should get this game. It takes cooperative, strategical teamwork in video games to a whole new level. Each role that you play feels distinct and makes you feel like you are directly contributing to the success or failure of your ship. PROS:- Distinctly different roles to play- Genuine feel of teamwork- Many customizable options available for your character and ships- Good tutorials and a rank system that help you build skill before jumping into matches with experienced players.- Very nice in-game communication tools if you don't like using a mic.CONS:- Graphics aren't the best- Community is relatively small- Having one or two bad players on a crew can ruin the experience for everyone- No single player options or players vs AI options

Posted: August 9, 2015
												Wow.. so..This game is incredible. So incredible that I would recommend it to anyone with three other friends that are willing to spend money on it too.But that's just that. If you don't have 3 other friends whom you can Skype or voice chat with.. don't even think about getting this game. It's not worth the annoyance. Yeah, there are voice chat options in-game but it all is pretty irrelevant because they're not going to listen to orders you give (if you're captain) and not all of them will know your lingo. The command "right, right, right, right" might be "AIM RIGHT" to them, when in fact you're meaning to get on the right gun. Or "left, uptop, barrage" might just mean "shoot randomly". It's not a game you can just sit down and enjoy casually. Every round is intense, thick with teamwork and if your team is properly put together.. there isn't much you can't do. If you aren't constantly updating your friends on the goings-ons of the ship.. YOU WILL DIE. If they can't listen to you.. YOU WILL DIE. Every win, every hit, every barrage will feel like you are personally on the ship.. you become almost intimate with your ship. When your balloon gets critically injured your ship sinks.. and so does your spirits as you mash the W key to ascend because the ground is coming up at a very fast rate.It's so ♥♥♥♥ing worth it if you can assemble a team of 3.

Posted: August 6, 2014
												An excellent game with an even better community, which is mainly what makes it so great. The gameplay itself is often manic, and extremely good fun - but you'll need to collaborate with your 3 other crewmates in order to take down enemy ships (I cannot stress enough how important it is to have good communication with your crew, as well as good tactics). The voice chat feature makes this very easy, but if you don't fancy speaking to strangers over the internet, there's a text chat option as well - most people are very friendly! Communication and familiarity with your crewmembers is greatly aided by the clan system, which forms the basis of the online community: you can get to know people in your clan and develop rivalries with other clans, against whom your clan may be pitted in the frequent tournaments that take place. Tactics play as important a part as execution in this game, with captains of the ship able to change ship loadouts to suit their crew and opponents; ship customisation is also available. All three roles of gunner, engineer and pilot are very fun to play, and you'll soon find which one you like best - most people start with engineer as it is often the most straightforward, at least when you're new to the game. There is a fairly comprehensive tutorial system inbuilt, as well as the game forums for more information and excellent community guides. My only complaint would be that it takes a very long time to level up all of your classes, as this is done by earning achievements and not directly controlled by the amount of time spent playing the game: but this is clearly a deliberate choice made by the developers (who, incidentally, are very active in the community) and you still have a great time playing the game.In short, an excellent little game that will keep you absorbed for a long time as you grow familiar with its nuances and finer tactics.

Posted: December 9, 2013
												I can't think of another co-operatively multiplayer game that has made me jump out of my seat and whoop for joy upon defeating an opponent.When your crew comes together and collectively out-manoeuvres, out-guns, and generally out-performs a rival crew, pummelling a hostile ship to pieces with co-ordinated effort and avoiding the worst that the enemy can throw back at you...The feeling you experience at that moment is what draws you back into the skies.I have piloted my ship through a passing cloud, hiding in ambush as an enemy ship approaches unawares. With a heavy carronade I have harried opponent engineers, pressuring them to keep their balloon functional as the rest of their dirigible degrades around them. And with swift reactions I have wrestled the fate of my ship and crew from the enemy's hands by repairing, maintaining, and empowering onboard systems and weapons to deny victory to my opponents.Gather a crew and take to the skies! You won't regret it.

Posted: June 11, 2015
												I first heard of this game when some friends of mine from a Let's Play community decided to do an Event in this game. I picked up the 4-pack on sale, and tried the tutorials.I'm gonna get this out of the way now. I'm sad to say it, but the tutorials are not very good at all. You get a really, really basic idea of the game, if you're paying close attention, but not really enough to be even basically competent. It took some good friends and a lot of trial and error to be even a little useful. That said... This game is pretty damned great. It's a 4-player co-op, but it's nothing like spiritual cousins like Left 4 Dead, though you probably didn't expect it to be... because, you know, airships. Where the tutorials are slow, the game is really, really fast paced once you get into it. I strongly, strongly recommend you get a mic, and USE IT. You'll need to be able to communicate well with your crew, and almost as importantly with the other ship(s) on your team. One really competent crew can survive an awful lot and dish out a lot of damage, but they'll need to be cross-talking constantly, making sure everyone is on the same page, and the game is too fast paced for the text chat to be very useful for this. The built-in voice-chat is pretty good, though I think it likely that many players will use a dedicated voice chat client.The three roles are very different, though there is some overlap. Anyone, no matter their role, can do any job, but your role will give you more tools that will help you to do your job better. You gain experience while playing and level up, but the levels mostly designate your experience, though they do unlock cosmetic options, tools and eventually more ships. Anyway, if you're a fan of co-op competitive games, and you're looking for something a little different, this game is excellent, and definitely worth a look.

Posted: April 11, 2015
												I love this game. A lot. Probably as much as I loved Natural Selection, Dota, or Mount & Blade. (TF maybe too)Rewarding, updated, good looking, and balanced. The community is great. The matchmaking is reasonably good, and there are great stats, achievements & visuals to unlock/purchase (clothing, paints/dyes themes none of which gives you advantage in game mechanics, so there is ZERO PAY TO WIN).The difficulty and complexity scales from novice to pro nicely so there's almost always something new to learn, a trick or experience you haven't done before.Short description:Exciting team-based gameplay. Not like anything you have played before most likely.Crew combat airships of various specialties/layouts in 2v2, 3v3 or 4v4 ships versus ships.Each ship has a crew of at least 1 pilot and 3 ai crew, or up to 4 players per ship crew (including pilot).Usually that means a driver, a gunner and some engineers who split their time repairing damage and shooting extra guns.The learning curve for crew (non-driver) is pretty easy, the pilot is a bit more tricky (flying in 3 dimensions and leading your crew usually at the same time, often on voicecomm).A match generally consists of a lobby (either deathmatch; first team to a certain number of kills, king of the hill, or cap the flag/KotH), where a map is voted on, and both teams' ship, crew, and weapons setups are organized.. before the timer ends and the match starts (plenty of time generally).During a match you try put enemy ships in your weapons range/arc and knock out their components like guns, balloon, armor, or engines, with the hull under the armor being the finisher.Each weapon, and ammo have their own thing they are "mostly" used for, and a more strict effective range plus turning limit, so the pilot must work with the gunners to give the crew good lines of fire etc.Non-pilots also use spotting scopes to tag enemy ships with a bracket for easier identification at range. Ships can use cover of terrain and clouds to evade detection/damage. While piloting skills are often the most influential single factor in win:loss, a crew of really bad humans can contribute to a loss more than having ai crew sometimes, and a good human crew is ALWAYS better than the 'bots'.The view from the open air deck of your ship is nice, and you as a crewperson are immune to enemy gun fire, but you can fall off, which leads to a realistic fall-time and death with an immediate respawn onboard. Once familiar with the ship layouts this will rarely, if ever, happen, and even if it does, it isn't a match ender.As a ship is damaged, the guys with repair hammers go to work to get things repaired, which is pretty fast paced and well done as a mechanic. They also do firefighting and buffing on ship components. The hull itself cannot be repaired during the match, which is why ships want to try to keep their armor intact as much as possible to protect the hull/structure. And of course if you lose your balloon you fall out of the sky, no engines make you a sitting duck etc.People are nice and will 'teach you the trade' "on the job" quickly.9/10Highly recommended if you like teamwork games.

Posted: February 13, 2014
												Guns of Icarus Online is an absolutely spectacular game, certainly worth the price (especially if you and three friends all pool your money and get the 4-pack). Given that ship crews are four people strong (captain, engineer and two gunners in my group) this works out well.For an online-only game, and in absolute terms, the community is fantastic - never once have I encountered a rude player and novices actually get a chance to learn the game rather than be bullied out by the more-experienced players (looking at you, LoL).Feature-wise, the game is very dependant on teamwork, no single ship is overpowered and there are many different weapon loadouts for each given ship, making spotting and target identification a must-have skill. Each player can take five items of equipment (one sailing tool, one engineering tool, one gunnery tool; plus two extras for their chosen class), which allows for even more customisation in fighting style. The levelling system is strange but it works - achievements count towards levels, with so many achievements being needed to level up. Crucially for an online-only game, there is absolutely no pay-to-win.The game looks amazing, there's no doubt about that. Everything is beautifully rendered and designed. The soundtrack and in-game SFX are also incredible.The only downside I can think of is that if the game lags, it can have a severe impact on the entire crew's effectiveness, especially if the Captain is the one with the lag issues.

Posted: November 27, 2013
												Guns of Icarus Online is a refreshingly unique experience that deserves some attention. The game plays out by pitting several 4-player crews against each other in team-based airship battles. Every member of the crew has a role to fill and your success or failure depends entirely on you crews ability to function as a cohesive unit. Engineers will repair the damage your ship takes in combat, pilots fly the ship and are responsible for lining up shots, and gunners keep the pressure on the enemy. There is a good variety of ships to choose from each with their own strengths and weaknesses, and a multitude of weapons which can be slotted in different locations on the ship. Creating the right ship build with the right crew consistently yeilds a satisfying result. That said a twitch shooter this is not. The weapons are slow to fire and slower to reload, coordination is everything and there is absolutely no room for lone wolf tactics in this game. If you are looking for a game that rewards patience and teamwork look no further, pick up the 4-pack and invite some friends. If you feel like giving the devs a little more support there is an in-game cash shop as well but it only contains cosmetic items. Character unlocks are purely cosmetic as well meaning no player will be at a competitive disadvantage, save for tackling the games initial learning curve. I have been very happy with the game's balance thus far with the one exception that the random spawn locations during objective based matches can be wildly unfair (and that too many players fly the noobie Pyramideon and Goldfish ships but thats just a personal gripe). The community as a whole has been very helpfull and fun to interact with and the developers have made it clear that there are big things in store for the future of the game. This game could have easily been a pay-to-win copy & paste frag fest but instead the developers made something truely special. If it wasn't clear already I highly recommend this game and hope to see you in the skies.

Posted: June 3, 2014
												This game is great! It is kind of like a real-time version of FTL with movement, in which you control an individual crew member. The roles are all fun to play and each one is important to your crew as a whole. The gameplay is great, requiring a decent amount of planning and multitasking ability to master, and players can develop their own unique styles of play which keeps the game very replayable. I do wish that there were more ships and maps though, but the ones that do exist are great. Each map is made in a pretty unique way which emphasizes certain mechanics, and each ship has a niche to fill on the playing field which still allows for plenty of creativity.The overall polish of the game is decent - it's a bit buggy in some places and the graphics are not AAA quality, but the gameplay makes up for it completely.
